rok commented on pull request #11818:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11818#issuecomment-994144723


   This is getting review ready, couple of issues remaining:
   * `RoundTemporal`, `CeilTemporal` and `FloorTemporal` could maybe be templated from a single struct
   * `Nonexistent` in `RoundTemporalOptions` might be unnecessary as we assume timestamps are in UTC so they always exist. Probably holds for `Ambiguous` too.
   * Test data needs some work, especially pre-1970 and edge-cases.


--

   > * `Nonexistent` in `RoundTemporalOptions` might be unnecessary as we assume timestamps are in UTC so they always exist. Probably holds for `Ambiguous` too.
   
   Would we want to eventually support rounding in a timezone? (That can be deferred since I can see that getting tricky.) e.g. rounding to the hour may differ in a timezone that is xx:30 offset from UTC.

Review comment:
       I'm not exactly sure myself. Here it [looks like quarter](https://github.com/tidyverse/lubridate/blob/9cece5680d0280c5cd1ccdbc9309ccb4724b3a34/R/round.r#L199-L201) but from looking at output it seems to be shifted a month back (Winter runs Dec 1 - March 1 etc) and it's not stable - first season start moves depending on the multiple.
   I'll just add quarter and we can put this in if desired later.

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

fields.description: This would enable us to implement the linked R ticket

comments.body: Hmm... what are the desired semantics here?

Actually; this might be a bit different to just extending floor/ceiling/round - we want to be able to support the {{lubridate}} functions here: https://lubridate.tidyverse.org/reference/round_date.html

We basically would like to be able to round a date, specifying which component to round it to (in {{lubridate}} valid value for {{unit}} are second, minute, hour, day, week, month, bimonth, quarter, season, halfyear and year), and account for the additional complication of specifying the day on which the week starts when rounding by week.

It appears pandas has a similar operation: [https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.Series.dt.round.html] which also has options for handling ambiguous/nonexistent dates. Neither allow you to control the rounding mode (and it is not specified for Pandas). Postgres only implements truncation: [https://www.postgresql.org/docs/14/functions-datetime.html#FUNCTIONS-DATETIME-TRUNC]
[~lidavidm] I'm thinking to pick this up. Anything I take into account?

[~rokm] I don't think there's anything in particular. There's just quite a range of options to account for (Pandas has the ambiguous/nonexistent timestamp options, but only implements rounding; R implements truncate/round/ceiling and lets you control the start-of-week).

> It appears pandas has a similar operation: https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.Series.dt.round.html which also has options for handling ambiguous/nonexistent dates. Neither allow you to control the rounding mode (and it is not specified for Pandas).

Pandas has separate {{ceil}} and {{floor}} methods for timestamps as well for different rounding modes (but it's true that {{round}} doesn't really specify how it is rounding)

[~jorisvandenbossche] I plan to make separate kernels for round/floor/ceil.
It appears rounding in pandas (and I suspect in lubridate) is done to time intervals, which seems fine for intervals of day and smaller. However it would be nice to round to week/month/etc where the result would be "calendar rounded" instead of "interval rounded". So I'm trying to set that up, please stop me if you disagree.

Pandas indeed only implements rounding to "fixed size" frequencies/intervals (so day or less). But I think that's more a practical reason that this is not supported (easier to implement). But so I think it is fine to add in Arrow if we have the utilities for that (through date.h)
